STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 29, 2020
Suzanne Lewis
Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee & Hillsdale
199 N. Broad Street
Adrian, MI 49221
RE: License #: CB460308844
Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee & Hillsdale
123 E. Maumee St.
Adrian, MI 49221
Dear Ms. Lewis:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
12/22/2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Repeat violations must identify why the previous CAP failed.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB460308844
Licensee Name: Catholic Charities of Jacksn, Lenw, & Hillsd
Licensee Address: 199 North Broad Street
Adrian, MI 49221
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 263-2191
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Suzanne Lewis, Designee
Name of Facility: Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee &
Hillsdale
Facility Address: 123 E. Maumee St.
Adrian, MI 49221
Facility Telephone #: (517) 263-2191
Original Issuance Date: 07/20/2010
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
CONTRACT-FOSTER CARE
CONTRACT-ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): Video Entrance-12/08/20, onsite-12/14/20, video exit-12/22/20

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
SRM 200 Fingerprints.
CHRI ACCESS TO AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL
Personnel Training: SAT is required to be taken within six
months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access and every
two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for ensuring that all
personnel with CHRI access completes SAT timely.
Two of five applicable employees were late on their fingerprint security training
required every two years.
R 400.12205 Required staff.
(8) An agency shall employ or contract for a sufficient number of
competent staff to carry out the provisions covered by these
rules. The workload for each staff member shall not be more
than any of the following:
(a) Five social service workers per supervisor.
(b) Fifteen children assigned to a social services worker for
purposes of providing direct services in foster care, independent
living, adoption, or post adoption services or a combination
thereof.
(a) The agency was found to be noncompliant with the supervisory ratio, which was
determined to be at an average of 89% based on caseload summary reports for
October, August, and June (per MISEP).
(b) The agency was found to be noncompliant with foster care (94.3%) and licensing
(83%) staffing ratios based on caseload summary reports for October, August, and
June (per MISEP).
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the person
usually resides.
4

(ii) An entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state or Canadian provincial law
enforcement agency where the person usually resides.
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
(b) One of four current employee files reviewed was missing verification of
education.
(e) and (h) Two of two terminated employee files reviewed were found to be missing
out of State documentation of criminal history clearances and central registry
clearances as these employees resided outside of Michigan in the five years prior to
hire.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for a foster home license before a foster home
application is provided.
One of two enrolled homes reviewed was found to have provided the application
(signed 11/11/19) prior to the applicants receiving orientation (12/11/19).
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(2) An agency shall document foster home license changes in
the foster home record and shall communicate the changes
immediately to the department in the manner prescribed by the
department.
One of three licensing files reviewed was found to have the 3706 dated only 14 days
prior to expiration and was only by the supervisor. Additionally, there was no signed
3080 uploaded for this file. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report 03/24/20 and
corresponding CAP, 04/15/20. The agency must report why the previous CAP
failed and how they will ensure compliance.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
5

One of three borrowed bed files reviewed did not document that the foster parent
was willing to accept the specific foster child.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
One of three special evaluations reviewed did not document that the foster parent
was informed, in writing, that he or she has a right to have his or her written
response included as an attachment to the report. The letter sent to the foster parent
omitted this information. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report 03/24/20 and
corresponding CAP, 04/15/20. The agency must report why the previous CAP
failed and how they will ensure compliance. Although this is a repeat violation, it
is isolated and was a matter of the information being omitted from the form letter that
is usually sent. The agency may submit the same CAP as last year, as it appears to
be addressing the issue.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures.
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
Two of six foster care files were found to have late supervisory approvals on four of
six service plans. These supervisory approvals were observed to be between one
and ten days past the 14 permitted in policy.
Three of six foster care files were found to have missing and/or late caregiver
signatures.
Two of five applicable foster care files reviewed were found to have missing and/or
late birth parent signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report 03/24/20 and corresponding CAP,
04/15/20 and Renewal Report, 12/26/18, and corresponding CAP, 01/14/19. The
agency must report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure
compliance.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
6

(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
One applicable current foster care file reviewed was found to be missing
documentation that the foster parent was provided the required information in the
rule. The agency uploaded the document from the 8/28/20 change of placement
after the inspection but this document did not have the foster parent signature.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One of three current foster care files reviewed for a 30-day transfer plan was found
to have the plan completed about one month late.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Three of three adoptive family files reviewed were found to have completed the
adoptive family evaluations late. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report 03/24/20
and corresponding CAP, 04/15/20. The agency must report why the previous
CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
7

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included
in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE ENGAGEMENT AND PLACEMENT
One of two unlicensed relative files reviewed for foster care placements, was found
not to have an initial relative home study, 3130a, uploaded in MISACWIS.
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
One of eight foster care files reviewed was found to have a DHHS 69 completed for
caseworker change, however, the 69 was completed almost two months after the
change and not in the three business days outlined in the policy. This was an
isolated incident, and it appears the agency is making efforts to be compliant.
One of two closed foster care files contained the closing DHHS 69 but it was only
signed by the supervisor.
FOM 801 Medical Passports
Three of six current foster care files reviewed were found to have missing and/or
late medical passports. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report 03/24/20 and
corresponding CAP, 04/15/20 and Renewal Report, 12/26/18, and
corresponding CAP, 01/14/19. The agency must report why the previous CAPs
failed and how they will ensure compliance.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Five of six current foster care files reviewed were found to have missing FTMs or
FTMs that were completed but not within the 30 days prior to the service plans as
noted in policy.
FOM 722-06H TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER CONTACTS
Two of six current foster care files reviewed were found to have contacts entered
after the five days permitted in policy. These contacts were observed to be entered
between 14 and 52 days late. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report 03/24/20 and
corresponding CAP, 04/15/20 and Renewal Report, 12/26/18, and
corresponding CAP, 01/14/19. The agency must report why the previous CAPs
failed and how they will ensure compliance.
8

ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
Two of three adoption files reviewed were found to be noncompliant with the policy.
One of the two files was missing a quarterly report. The other file contained a
quarterly report with no supervisory signature.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 209
The agency was advised to ensure that orientation is clearly documented to be 16
hours for social service workers and supervisors.
R 327
The agency was advised to ensure that they clearly document what the foster
parents are told related to the allegations. Additionally, the agency was cautioned
against foster parents using one another as support persons during interviews in
some special evaluations where individual and separate interviews would be
warranted.
R 404
The agency was advised to ensure that all initial information is captured on their
initial placement information, including the full address of the birth parents. If
unknown, the agency should note that.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or incidents of
substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing period.
The agency has submitted no other acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. There were no special investigations
during this period. The DCWL Field Analyst report indicated no safety concerns.
9

There are 17 violations in this report, which is similar to the 15 found in the last
Interim Report. The agency should focus on the six repeat violations and ensure a
strong, measurable, attainable CAP is created for each.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
December 28, 2020
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 29, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
10
